newsArray.title: Sydney's weather cricket 'curse' strikes again and this time Riverina's been hit
creator: Andrew Moir
newsArray.description: Riverina was scheduled to contest Country Bash final on January 17.
newsArray.content: The inaugural grand final has just been postponed, due to the weather. / (min cost $ 8 ) or signup to continue reading was scheduled to play Greater Illawarra in the decider on Wednesday afternoon at Sydney Showground Stadium, prior to the Big Bash game between Sydney Thunder and Melbourne Renegades. Sydney has a 90 per cent chance of receiving between 2-15 millimetres on Wednesday and when combined with earlier rain, it was decided to delay the T20 game. A replacement date is yet to be announced. The news of the postponement won't surprise cricket fans. Sydney has the most washed-out days in Australian-based Test matches, with 26. And the 'curse' has been prominent recently, with seven of the last eight New Year's Tests interrupted by rain. Advertisement Sign up for our newsletter to stay up to date. newsArray.title: Cricket-Hamstring strain rules Williamson out of Pakistan T20 series
newsArray.description: (Reuters) - New Zealand test captain Kane Williamson will miss the final three matches in the Twenty20 series against Pakistan after suffering a minor hamstring strain, the team said on Tuesday. Read full story
newsArray.content: (Reuters) - New Zealand test captain Kane Williamson will miss the final three matches in the Twenty20 series against Pakistan after suffering a minor hamstring strain, the team said on Tuesday. Williamson, who has been hit with injuries in recent years, sustained the strain while batting in the second Twenty20 in Hamilton on Sunday, which the Black Caps won by 21 runs to take a 2-0 lead in the series. "A timeline for Williamson's rehabilitation and return to cricket is still being established with a goal of being ready for selection in the test series against South Africa," New Zealand Cricket said in a statement. New Zealand play an inexperienced South Africa team in two tests at Mount Maunganui and Hamilton in February. (Reporting by Nick Mulvenney, editing by Neil Fullick.)

Williamson, who has been hit with injuries in recent years, sustained the strain while batting in the second Twenty20 in Hamilton on Sunday, which the Black Caps won by 21 runs to take a 2-0 lead in the series. "A timeline for Williamson's rehabilitation and return to cricket is still being established with a goal of being ready for selection in the test series against South Africa," New Zealand Cricket said in a statement. newsArray.title: Inside Steve Smith‚Äôs final nets session before historic move for first Test against West Indies
newsArray.description: ADELAIDE ‚Äî It all started in typical Steve Smith fashion. There was a grumble, some sort of discomfort, or perhaps it was just a nervous tick.
newsArray.content: ADELAIDE ‚Äî It all started in typical Steve Smith fashion. There was a grumble, some sort of discomfort, or perhaps it was just a nervous tick. Ahead of his final net before becoming Australia‚Äôs next Test opener, Smith used his clenched fist to bang at various spots around his left hip, before undergoing extended stretching and mobility exercises. With a fully-kitted Travis Head and Matthew Renshaw already going through their paces on Tuesday, one day before the first Test against the West Indies, Smith had to get things right. Watch Australia v West Indies on Kayo Sports. Every Test, ODI and T20I Live with no ad breaks during play. New to Kayo? Start Your Free Trial Today > Eventually, he strapped on his gloves and a front pad, summoned coach Andrew McDonald to the far net, and started putting willow to leather. It was an optional training session behind the Adelaide Oval‚Äôs members stand ‚Äì already warm, and soon to be sweltering under afternoon sun ‚Äì and players could work as hard, or light, as they pleased. A watchful Steve Smith in the nets. Source: FOX SPORTS For Smith, it was the latter, receiving just 20 minutes of exclusively front-foot throwdowns from his coach, armed with a new-to-newish ball. That‚Äôs not to say the mood was light, however. Every miscued drive from Smith was met with the utter disgust that you might suspect from a batter who averages nearly 60 in Test match cricket. ‚ÄúF**k off,‚Äù Smith muttered after one drive through midwicket didn‚Äôt come off. Brendon Julian is our special guest on the latest edition of Fox Cricket‚Äôs The Follow On podcast. Listen below, or tap to listen in iTunes , Spotify or Omny . Smith promptly belted the leather off the next ball through the covers, and had a look that was equal parts satisfaction and lingering anger from the ball before. Very little was exchanged between McDonald and his new opening batter, who will on Wednesday face the new ball in the first Test of the post David Warner era. The most said between the two was when Smith stopped the next throwdown to readjust his pads, much to the delight of McDonald who was working overtime to keep up with the batter‚Äôs appetite for the next delivery. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm happy to have a longer wait between throws,‚Äù McDonald told Smith with a smile. Steve Smith will open the batting against the West Indies. Source: FOX SPORTS It was a heavily-restricted session, in both length and variety. The 20-minute session consisted only of McDonald‚Äôs wanger-less throwdowns that were exclusively on a full length, and didn‚Äôt force Smith into any uncomfortable areas. That is likely all Smith demanded to get into the right headspace to bat at the top of the order, where he‚Äôs set to face more pitched-up deliveries from the swinging new ball early, as opposed to short-pitched tactics. Steve Smith warms up before his session. Source: FOX SPORTS Smith did briefly linger after the 20 minutes were up, looking a picture of dissatisfaction before he slipped away, back to the changerooms, by himself. Cricket Australia told foxsports.com.au that there is no injury concern with Smith, whose vast array of idiosyncrasies are often not telling of any genuine issue. Nonetheless, Australia will hope to see a happier Smith on Wednesday ‚Äì the first day of what could be the final chapter of his Test career.

newsArray.title: Parthiv Patel backs Axar Patel ahead of Ravindra Jadeja for T20 World Cup
newsArray.description: Parthiv Patel backs Axar Patel ahead of Ravindra Jadeja for T20 World Cup
newsArray.content: Listen to Story Parthiv Patel said that he would prefer Axar Patel over Ravindra Jadeja going into the T20 World Cup 2024 to be held in the West Indies and United States of America (USA). Axar has been in impressive form in India‚Äôs ongoing T20I series against Afghanistan. He is currently the leading wicket-taker, having picked up four wickets from two matches at an economy rate if 5. Parthiv said that it‚Äôs tough to get on top of Axar because of the pace at which he bowls. ‚ÄúHis strength is the accuracy with which he bowls with. He doesn‚Äôt bowl in the slot, most of the time. If you want to hit him, you have to hit him use the feet or make room. And using feet is not easy against him because of the pace with which he bowls,‚Äù Parthiv was quoted as saying on Jio Cinemas. Parthiv was of the opinion that having the ability and skills to bowl in the powerplay makes Axar a cricketer, ‚Äúwho can perform everywhere‚Äù. ‚ÄúHe is someone who can perform everywhere. In this T20 format, yes, we talk about Ravindra Jadeja, but I think Axar gives you that stability. He bowls in powerplays, and it makes him an even better cricketer,‚Äù he stated. In the second T20I on Sunday at the Holkar Cricket Stadium in Indore, after he finished with figures of 4-0-17-2. He got the wickets of Ibrahim Zadran and Gulbadin Naib to make sure that India restricted the Afghans to 172 on an excellent pitch to bat on. Axar hasn‚Äôt got a chance to bat in the series, but Parthiv said that he brings in more value to the team due to his power-hitting ability. ‚ÄúIn this format, yes. I think Axar brings in more variety. He doesn‚Äôt bowl in a one-dimensional way. He bats at any number. If you look at this Indian team, you need a power hitter, and Axar brings that. And in this format, Axar is ahead of Jadeja, as far as I am concerned,‚Äù Parthiv added. India‚Äôs third and final T20I against Afghanistan is on January 17 at the M Chinnaswamy Stadium in Bangalore.

newsArray.title: Kane Williamson ruled out for remainder of T20I series against Pakistan
newsArray.description: New Zealand's white-ball skipper Kane Williamson has been ruled out of the last three T20Is against Pakistan following a hamstring injury that he suffered during the second T20I at Seddon Park in Hamilton on Sunday, January 14.
newsArray.content: New Zealand's white-ball skipper has been ruled out of the last three T20Is against Pakistan following a hamstring injury that he suffered during the second T20I at Seddon Park in Hamilton on Sunday, January 14. Williamson, 33, was due to miss the third T20I anyway but has now been sidelined from the entire series. The Kiwi skipper underwent a scan on Monday that confirmed a minor hamstring strain which he picked up while batting during the 2nd T20I. The Blackcaps captain was due to be replaced by Josh Clarkson in the 3rd T20I but a shoulder injury to the latter jeopardised his chances of coming in as a replacement and now Will Young will fill in for Williamson. A statement released by New Zealand Cricket mentioned that "a timeline for Williamson‚Äôs rehabilitation and return to cricket is still being established with a goal of being ready for selection in the Test Series against South Africa starting next month". New Zealand's head coach Garry Stead mentioned that wicketkeeper-batter Tim Seifert will take Williamson's place in the playing XI and most probably take the wicketkeeping duties from Devon Conway. The hosts have been fairly clinical in terms of their performance in the ongoing series against the Shaheen Shah Afridi-led Pakistan. The Kiwi batters have been able to demolish the Pakistani attack in both games and posted 226 and 194 in both outings. While the first T20I at Eden Park in Auckland turned out to be a walk in the park for New Zealand as they emerged victorious by 46 runs, the second fixture at Seddon Park in Hamilton was comparatively evenly contested and witnessed the home side cross the finishing line by 21 runs. The 3rd T20I of the series will be played at the University Oval in Dunedin on Wednesday, January 17.

newsArray.title: Bowling Baptist draw Bradley in Craven League‚Äôs Manorlands Plate
newsArray.description: TWO championship-winning sides will meet in the first round of the Timothy Taylor‚Äôs Craven League‚Äôs Manorlands Plate this season.
newsArray.content: TWO championship-winning sides will meet in the first round of the Timothy Taylor‚Äôs Craven League‚Äôs Manorlands Plate this season. Bowling Baptist, who finished top of the pile in Division Three in 2023, will be at home to Bradley, who were the front-runners in Division Two. Apart from that tie at Scotchman Road, there are two other first-round ties, with Eldwick & Gilstead entertaining Sutton, and league runners-up Gargrave hosting Denholme, who, like Sutton, were demoted from the top flight last season. The matches, arranged by mutual consent and played in The Hundred format, must be played on or before Thursday July 4, with money raised in the competition going to Manorlands Hospice at Oxenhope. The winners of the three first-round ties will all be at home in the quarter-finals. Eldwick & Gilstead or Sutton will face Wilsden, the victors in the Bowling Baptist v Bradley contest will meet Keighley III, and either Manorlands Plate 2023 finalists Gargrave or Denholme will play Skipton CI. The other quarter-final, with ties to be completed on or before Friday, August 2, is 2023 semi-finalists Silsden at home to holders Riddlesden. The finals day is pencilled in for Keighley Cricket Club on Sunday, August 25. Semi-finals are at 10am and 1.30pm, with the final at 4.30pm.

newsArray.title: Quetta, Lahore, Rawalpindi win National Women‚Äôs T20 openers
creator: Our Staff Reporter
newsArray.description: LAHORE - The opening day of National Women‚Äôs T20 Tournament2023-24 saw action unfold at three venues across Rawalpindi and Islamabad.
newsArray.content: LAHORE - The opening day of National Women‚Äôs T20 Tournament2023-24 saw action unfold at three venues across Rawalpindi and Islamabad. Quetta edged over Karachi in a final-over finish at Shoaib Akhtar Cricket Stadium, registering a win by six wickets. At Ayub Park Ground, Lahore dominated over Multan with a 10-wicket win after the latter were bowled out for 69. Rawalpindi cruised to a comfortable victory by seven wickets against Peshawar at the Diamond Club Ground. SCORES IN BRIEF QUETTA 121-4, 19.5 overs (Fareeha Mahmood 63, Tuba Hassan 34*; Rameen Shamim 1-16) beat KARACHI 119-6, 20 overs (Javeria Khan 74*, Maham Manzoor 17*; Khairun Nisa 3-14) by 6 wickets. LAHORE 73-0, 8.4 overs (Sadaf Shams 35*, Sidra Amin 31*) beat MULTAN 69 all out, 19.1 overs (Umm-e-Hani 20, Saiqa Riaz 14*; Ghulam Fatima 3-13, Nashra Sandhu 2-1) by 10 wickets. PESHAWAR 51 all out, 12 overs (Raahima Syed 13, Aleena Shah 13; Tania Saeed 3-4, Waheeda Akhtar 2-1, Aliya Riaz 2-13) beat RAWALPINDI 52-3, 6.2 overs (Aliya Riaz 23; Tehzeeb Shah 1-11) by 7 wickets.

newsArray.description: (Reuters) - New Zealand test captain Kane Williamson will miss the final three matches in the Twenty20 series against Pakistan after suffering a minor hamstring strain, the team said on Tuesday. Read full story
newsArray.content: (Reuters) - New Zealand test captain Kane Williamson will miss the final three matches in the Twenty20 series against Pakistan after suffering a minor hamstring strain, the team said on Tuesday. Williamson, who has been hit with injuries in recent years, sustained the strain while batting in the second Twenty20 in Hamilton on Sunday, which the Black Caps won by 21 runs to take a 2-0 lead in the series. "A timeline for Williamson's rehabilitation and return to cricket is still being established with a goal of being ready for selection in the test series against South Africa," New Zealand Cricket said in a statement. New Zealand play an inexperienced South Africa team in two tests at Mount Maunganui and Hamilton in February. (Reporting by Nick Mulvenney, editing by Neil Fullick.)

newsArray.title: Kane Williamson ruled out for remainder of T20I series against Pakistan
newsArray.description: New Zealand's white-ball skipper Kane Williamson has been ruled out of the last three T20Is against Pakistan following a hamstring injury that he suffered during the second T20I at Seddon Park in Hamilton on Sunday, January 14.
newsArray.content: New Zealand's white-ball skipper has been ruled out of the last three T20Is against Pakistan following a hamstring injury that he suffered during the second T20I at Seddon Park in Hamilton on Sunday, January 14. Williamson, 33, was due to miss the third T20I anyway but has now been sidelined from the entire series. The Kiwi skipper underwent a scan on Monday that confirmed a minor hamstring strain which he picked up while batting during the 2nd T20I. The Blackcaps captain was due to be replaced by Josh Clarkson in the 3rd T20I but a shoulder injury to the latter jeopardised his chances of coming in as a replacement and now Will Young will fill in for Williamson. A statement released by New Zealand Cricket mentioned that "a timeline for Williamson‚Äôs rehabilitation and return to cricket is still being established with a goal of being ready for selection in the Test Series against South Africa starting next month". New Zealand's head coach Garry Stead mentioned that wicketkeeper-batter Tim Seifert will take Williamson's place in the playing XI and most probably take the wicketkeeping duties from Devon Conway. The hosts have been fairly clinical in terms of their performance in the ongoing series against the Shaheen Shah Afridi-led Pakistan. The Kiwi batters have been able to demolish the Pakistani attack in both games and posted 226 and 194 in both outings. While the first T20I at Eden Park in Auckland turned out to be a walk in the park for New Zealand as they emerged victorious by 46 runs, the second fixture at Seddon Park in Hamilton was comparatively evenly contested and witnessed the home side cross the finishing line by 21 runs. The 3rd T20I of the series will be played at the University Oval in Dunedin on Wednesday, January 17.

newsArray.title: Bowling Baptist draw Bradley in Craven League‚Äôs Manorlands Plate
newsArray.description: TWO championship-winning sides will meet in the first round of the Timothy Taylor‚Äôs Craven League‚Äôs Manorlands Plate this season.
newsArray.content: TWO championship-winning sides will meet in the first round of the Timothy Taylor‚Äôs Craven League‚Äôs Manorlands Plate this season. Bowling Baptist, who finished top of the pile in Division Three in 2023, will be at home to Bradley, who were the front-runners in Division Two. Apart from that tie at Scotchman Road, there are two other first-round ties, with Eldwick & Gilstead entertaining Sutton, and league runners-up Gargrave hosting Denholme, who, like Sutton, were demoted from the top flight last season. The matches, arranged by mutual consent and played in The Hundred format, must be played on or before Thursday July 4, with money raised in the competition going to Manorlands Hospice at Oxenhope. The winners of the three first-round ties will all be at home in the quarter-finals. Eldwick & Gilstead or Sutton will face Wilsden, the victors in the Bowling Baptist v Bradley contest will meet Keighley III, and either Manorlands Plate 2023 finalists Gargrave or Denholme will play Skipton CI. The other quarter-final, with ties to be completed on or before Friday, August 2, is 2023 semi-finalists Silsden at home to holders Riddlesden. The finals day is pencilled in for Keighley Cricket Club on Sunday, August 25. Semi-finals are at 10am and 1.30pm, with the final at 4.30pm.

newsArray.title: Quetta, Lahore, Rawalpindi win National Women‚Äôs T20 openers
creator: Our Staff Reporter
newsArray.description: LAHORE - The opening day of National Women‚Äôs T20 Tournament2023-24 saw action unfold at three venues across Rawalpindi and Islamabad.
newsArray.content: LAHORE - The opening day of National Women‚Äôs T20 Tournament2023-24 saw action unfold at three venues across Rawalpindi and Islamabad. Quetta edged over Karachi in a final-over finish at Shoaib Akhtar Cricket Stadium, registering a win by six wickets. At Ayub Park Ground, Lahore dominated over Multan with a 10-wicket win after the latter were bowled out for 69. Rawalpindi cruised to a comfortable victory by seven wickets against Peshawar at the Diamond Club Ground. SCORES IN BRIEF QUETTA 121-4, 19.5 overs (Fareeha Mahmood 63, Tuba Hassan 34*; Rameen Shamim 1-16) beat KARACHI 119-6, 20 overs (Javeria Khan 74*, Maham Manzoor 17*; Khairun Nisa 3-14) by 6 wickets. LAHORE 73-0, 8.4 overs (Sadaf Shams 35*, Sidra Amin 31*) beat MULTAN 69 all out, 19.1 overs (Umm-e-Hani 20, Saiqa Riaz 14*; Ghulam Fatima 3-13, Nashra Sandhu 2-1) by 10 wickets. PESHAWAR 51 all out, 12 overs (Raahima Syed 13, Aleena Shah 13; Tania Saeed 3-4, Waheeda Akhtar 2-1, Aliya Riaz 2-13) beat RAWALPINDI 52-3, 6.2 overs (Aliya Riaz 23; Tehzeeb Shah 1-11) by 7 wickets.

newsArray.title: Sydney's weather cricket 'curse' strikes again and this time Riverina's been hit
creator: Andrew Moir
newsArray.description: Riverina was scheduled to contest Country Bash final on January 17.
newsArray.content: The inaugural grand final has just been postponed, due to the weather. / (min cost $ 8 ) or signup to continue reading was scheduled to play Greater Illawarra in the decider on Wednesday afternoon at Sydney Showground Stadium, prior to the Big Bash game between Sydney Thunder and Melbourne Renegades. Sydney has a 90 per cent chance of receiving between 2-15 millimetres on Wednesday and when combined with earlier rain, it was decided to delay the T20 game. A replacement date is yet to be announced. The news of the postponement won't surprise cricket fans. Sydney has the most washed-out days in Australian-based Test matches, with 26. And the 'curse' has been prominent recently, with seven of the last eight New Year's Tests interrupted by rain. Advertisement Sign up for our newsletter to stay up to date. We care about the protection of your data. Read our . Advertisement

newsArray.title: Cricket-Hamstring strain rules Williamson out of Pakistan T20 series
newsArray.description: (Reuters) - New Zealand test captain Kane Williamson will miss the final three matches in the Twenty20 series against Pakistan after suffering a minor hamstring strain, the team said on Tuesday. Read full story
newsArray.content: (Reuters) - New Zealand test captain Kane Williamson will miss the final three matches in the Twenty20 series against Pakistan after suffering a minor hamstring strain, the team said on Tuesday. Williamson, who has been hit with injuries in recent years, sustained the strain while batting in the second Twenty20 in Hamilton on Sunday, which the Black Caps won by 21 runs to take a 2-0 lead in the series. "A timeline for Williamson's rehabilitation and return to cricket is still being established with a goal of being ready for selection in the test series against South Africa," New Zealand Cricket said in a statement. New Zealand play an inexperienced South Africa team in two tests at Mount Maunganui and Hamilton in February. (Reporting by Nick Mulvenney, editing by Neil Fullick.)

newsArray.title: Inside Steve Smith‚Äôs final nets session before historic move for first Test against West Indies
newsArray.description: ADELAIDE ‚Äî It all started in typical Steve Smith fashion. There was a grumble, some sort of discomfort, or perhaps it was just a nervous tick.
newsArray.content: ADELAIDE ‚Äî It all started in typical Steve Smith fashion. There was a grumble, some sort of discomfort, or perhaps it was just a nervous tick. Ahead of his final net before becoming Australia‚Äôs next Test opener, Smith used his clenched fist to bang at various spots around his left hip, before undergoing extended stretching and mobility exercises. With a fully-kitted Travis Head and Matthew Renshaw already going through their paces on Tuesday, one day before the first Test against the West Indies, Smith had to get things right. Watch Australia v West Indies on Kayo Sports. Every Test, ODI and T20I Live with no ad breaks during play. New to Kayo? Start Your Free Trial Today > Eventually, he strapped on his gloves and a front pad, summoned coach Andrew McDonald to the far net, and started putting willow to leather. It was an optional training session behind the Adelaide Oval‚Äôs members stand ‚Äì already warm, and soon to be sweltering under afternoon sun ‚Äì and players could work as hard, or light, as they pleased. A watchful Steve Smith in the nets. Source: FOX SPORTS For Smith, it was the latter, receiving just 20 minutes of exclusively front-foot throwdowns from his coach, armed with a new-to-newish ball. That‚Äôs not to say the mood was light, however. Every miscued drive from Smith was met with the utter disgust that you might suspect from a batter who averages nearly 60 in Test match cricket. ‚ÄúF**k off,‚Äù Smith muttered after one drive through midwicket didn‚Äôt come off. Brendon Julian is our special guest on the latest edition of Fox Cricket‚Äôs The Follow On podcast. Listen below, or tap to listen in iTunes , Spotify or Omny . Smith promptly belted the leather off the next ball through the covers, and had a look that was equal parts satisfaction and lingering anger from the ball before. Very little was exchanged between McDonald and his new opening batter, who will on Wednesday face the new ball in the first Test of the post David Warner era. The most said between the two was when Smith stopped the next throwdown to readjust his pads, much to the delight of McDonald who was working overtime to keep up with the batter‚Äôs appetite for the next delivery. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm happy to have a longer wait between throws,‚Äù McDonald told Smith with a smile. Steve Smith will open the batting against the West Indies. Source: FOX SPORTS It was a heavily-restricted session, in both length and variety. The 20-minute session consisted only of McDonald‚Äôs wanger-less throwdowns that were exclusively on a full length, and didn‚Äôt force Smith into any uncomfortable areas. That is likely all Smith demanded to get into the right headspace to bat at the top of the order, where he‚Äôs set to face more pitched-up deliveries from the swinging new ball early, as opposed to short-pitched tactics. Steve Smith warms up before his session. Source: FOX SPORTS Smith did briefly linger after the 20 minutes were up, looking a picture of dissatisfaction before he slipped away, back to the changerooms, by himself. Cricket Australia told foxsports.com.au that there is no injury concern with Smith, whose vast array of idiosyncrasies are often not telling of any genuine issue. Nonetheless, Australia will hope to see a happier Smith on Wednesday ‚Äì the first day of what could be the final chapter of his Test career.

newsArray.title: Parthiv Patel backs Axar Patel ahead of Ravindra Jadeja for T20 World Cup
newsArray.description: Parthiv Patel backs Axar Patel ahead of Ravindra Jadeja for T20 World Cup
newsArray.content: Listen to Story Parthiv Patel said that he would prefer Axar Patel over Ravindra Jadeja going into the T20 World Cup 2024 to be held in the West Indies and United States of America (USA). Axar has been in impressive form in India‚Äôs ongoing T20I series against Afghanistan. He is currently the leading wicket-taker, having picked up four wickets from two matches at an economy rate if 5. Parthiv said that it‚Äôs tough to get on top of Axar because of the pace at which he bowls. ‚ÄúHis strength is the accuracy with which he bowls with. He doesn‚Äôt bowl in the slot, most of the time. If you want to hit him, you have to hit him use the feet or make room. And using feet is not easy against him because of the pace with which he bowls,‚Äù Parthiv was quoted as saying on Jio Cinemas. Parthiv was of the opinion that having the ability and skills to bowl in the powerplay makes Axar a cricketer, ‚Äúwho can perform everywhere‚Äù. ‚ÄúHe is someone who can perform everywhere. In this T20 format, yes, we talk about Ravindra Jadeja, but I think Axar gives you that stability. He bowls in powerplays, and it makes him an even better cricketer,‚Äù he stated. In the second T20I on Sunday at the Holkar Cricket Stadium in Indore, after he finished with figures of 4-0-17-2. He got the wickets of Ibrahim Zadran and Gulbadin Naib to make sure that India restricted the Afghans to 172 on an excellent pitch to bat on. Axar hasn‚Äôt got a chance to bat in the series, but Parthiv said that he brings in more value to the team due to his power-hitting ability. ‚ÄúIn this format, yes. I think Axar brings in more variety. He doesn‚Äôt bowl in a one-dimensional way. He bats at any number. If you look at this Indian team, you need a power hitter, and Axar brings that. And in this format, Axar is ahead of Jadeja, as far as I am concerned,‚Äù Parthiv added. India‚Äôs third and final T20I against Afghanistan is on January 17 at the M Chinnaswamy Stadium in Bangalore.
